Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2019 07:44AM - edited Apr 11, 2019 07:44AM by Flynn I was taking meds for migraines before I was diagnosed. We attributed my daily naps to the meds. In retrospect, we probably missed an early symptom. Otherwise, I was exercising and in good shape but I did feel an unusual fatigue. No way to tell now for sure what caused it but my b/w wasn't ideal from my 1st MO appt.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2018 02:02PM - edited Oct 5, 2018 02:04PM by Flynn There really is a huge variance in how people's hair comes back. For those of you who continue to lose hair after treatment ends, I think you could count from the end of the hair loss forward. By the time I finished, there was not an eyelash or hair left, so I started progressing from that point. I also think hormonal therapy can impact tho I don't speak from personal experience. I found stopping wearing the caps awkward for a couple days and then very liberating. GL to all of you! VL22, thanks for your kind words! Last time I got my hair cut the stylist played up the curls and my husband asked me if I got a permðŸ˜‚. I do miss being able to pull my hair back when I work out but I'm getting used to my new look. Also congrats on ringing the bell Ingerp!

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2017 02:12PM Flynn wrote: Peachy, ha ha I know what you mean about reverting to where we started as babies. The steroids I take are making my face puffy, so my face is wrinkle free at 47! Not my preferred look but oh well. Lovepugs, yep we've got to get humor where we can! Limonia, I'm wearing eyeliner to give my eyes some definition too. I find I smudge it, tho. I'll have to see if I have any liquid liner, might last better. Thanks for the info Agatha! I read a little about microblading after your last post. Sounds really like interesting, I can see a gentle version would be better especially if wbc counts are down at all. Three years is so long for it to last! I have a friend who had bc a couple years ago and her biggest fear was getting out of the shower and finding her eyebrows were gone. My eyebrow loss kind of snuck up on me. They made it thru ac but left during taxol except a couple stray hairs. I've started wearing hats in public more except when my kids or their friends are around. I only wear the wig for a couple hours but heat has a lot to do with my discomfort and we're still getting up to 85 during the day. Sweating under the wig is so awful. Hot flashes don't help the whole situation! Stephanie-.it seems like there is a huge variance in hair growing back but I'm not that far yet as I'm still on Taxol.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2017 02:53PM Flynn wrote: Hi ladies! I went yesterday for my surgical consult and found out that I’m going to need radiation. My lymph nodes are clear but apparently with a tumor 5cm or more, radiation is standard. Anyhow, I see that several of you have mentioned fatigue. I have a husband with a very demanding job and 7 year old twins. We have 2 sitters who have been helping us get thru chemo (no family near us). Now I’m wondering if I’ll still need some help after I recover from my mastectomy. Can you share how much fatigue you’ve experienced? I know that everybody’s different but If I’m going to keep my sitter(s) I need to sort things out before they get other jobs. Thanks!
Posts.Title: Starting Radiation October 2017 DodgersGirl DodgersGirl

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2017 01:33PM - edited Oct 12, 2017 01:33PM by Flynn I'm sorry that you are having such a rough go of it! I can't speak to having gone through treatment 2x's but I am halfway thru 12 weeks of Taxol with carboplatin every 3rd week. I have needed two transfusions because the carbo has done a number on my blood. The weeks that my numbers dropped I also felt extreme fatigue. Maybe yournext blood draw will give you some answers or if not,it certainly might be the combination of drugs that you are doing. Best wishes!
Posts.Title: Taxotere and carboplatin a second time around embmom Groovywilma

Got some funny looks when we came out ðŸ¤£. I can't be the only one who's been down this road? Dx 2/2017, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIB, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 2/28/2017 AC Chemotherapy 9/1/2017 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxol (paclitaxel) Surgery 11/30/2017 Lymph node removal: Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Radiation Therapy 2/1/2018 Whole-breast: Breast, Chest wall Chemotherapy 8/1/2018 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Craziest place you’ve ever taken meds? Flynn Flynn

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2018 01:32PM Flynn wrote: Hey ladies. I’m not in your group, but I was scanning threads looking for help with an issue that I’m having. Anyhow, I noticed a couple of you mentioned peeling under your arms. I too had a heck of a time with that when I finished rads. The nurse recommended sticking on Telfa pads with aquaphor. It didn’t take long before the pad was bunched up and causing more discomfort. Eventually, I tried putting on a super soft tank top whose arm holescame up high under my arm pit and it helped so much. It stopped the skin on skin friction and didn’t bunch up. I thought I’d throw that out there in case it helps anyone else.:)
Posts.Title: MARCH 2018 starting RADIATION Veeder14 Beaverntx

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2019 05:49AM - edited Mar 2, 2019 05:49AM by Flynn I think it's great to use this sucky experience to get breasts that make you happier! I went from a b to a d after nursing my twins. I'm very happy to be returning to b-land with my upcoming diep. My sister got an implant and a reduction on the other side to make her breasts more symmetrical. She did rads and hasn't had issues. She had acellular dermal matrix. The skin on my radiated side is very different than my non-radiated side but I expect diep to resolve that issue. Good luck, whatever you choose
Posts.Title: Go up a cupsize? notdefined leftduetostupidmods

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2019 01:44PM - edited Jan 22, 2019 01:44PM by Flynn My sons were 6 yo when I was diagnosed, so I personally had a different situation. My mil was diagnosed when my dh was in grad school (early-mid 20's). She did not tell him or his siblings until after mastectomy & rads. Dh accepts that it was her choice to make but it's the 1st thing he and his 3 siblings mention when they talk about her 1st bout with bc. I would say that to this day, they wonder if she's being upfront when medical issues arise. Just another perspective for you to consider. Best wishes, whatever you do.
